This test was not about drones hitting jets in Class A airspace.  It was about drones hitting GA planes.  And the chances of that are pretty high in relative terms to hitting something while flying.  I personally have dodged several drones and nearly every pilot I know has a similar story.  A Bonanza doing 180kts one way, a drone doing 20kts the other way... time to declare an emergency and hope you can get on the ground before you have complete structural wing failure.

context: Wow.  After watching this video I think they should definitely outlaw drones in wind tunnels. :-)

I'm not sure I'd call this article fair and balanced.  Yes, if you shoot a drone at a wing in a wind tunnel it will damage it.  But the vast majority of drones are used for positive purposes.  Farmers use them to survey their fields, and they help them keep the use of chemicals to a minimum.  That's good for the environment, and it's cost effective for the farmers.  They perform various and sundry types of inspection jobs.  They're used in entertainment and sports for different camera angles.  Heck, drones were just used last week to survey storm damage after the hurricane.  And the list goes on and on.  You have to look at both sides of the argument.  That would be fair and balanced.

replies.context: Those are just the good drones that would never hurt anybody - well unless they turned on you. They are worried about the evil drones.

So deal with the people who misuse them.  But unfortunately personal responsibility seems to have gone out of style.

context: I think the chance of a drone hitting a wing edge is unlikely due to the air being pushed over and under the wing and the drone not having enough mass to overcome those forces.  However a hit on other plane surfaces is quite possible.

A Mooney M20 will not do 238 mph unless in a dive... its about 160 mph plane.  A few turbo versions might get close to 190.. speaking from memory.

replies.context: cruise speed (flat and level) for a Mooney M20 is 170 knots.....which is 197 mph  add that to a drone that is moving at 20-30 mph towards the plane....and what do you get?
I fly a mooney that will do 187kts.  That's 215mph.  So in a slow decent, 238mph is easy.  And this is not turbo charged.  Fix your memory or fly some newer stuff.
The most likely time for a collision is during the approach, when the plane will be low and in a descent.  The approach is also the worst time to have an IFE, not much time to recover.

context: Now do the 'test' with a C-17 Aerosky 6-rotor drone. Make sure it has all the optional stuff on it. INCLUDING a fully charged LiPo battery set. LiPo batteries are great power sources, but have a habit of catching on fire when damaged. Aircraft are built to withstand some damage. Burning batteries inside a wing or cockpit though, are something else all together.

context: That is quite the hole.  How about through a windshield, or a fuel tank in the wing?
Looks like the FAA will have to reduce the speed under 2000ft to 180kts in case a drone hits the windscreen.

I'm a drone user and I use them for photography on my vacations in order to get different angled shots that I would not otherwise be able to get.  I live within 5 miles of an airport and I've never had any trouble with the FAA, airport or anything else.  I think there is a huge misunderstanding of what drones are, what they can do and how they are used.   The biggest question I get from people is they want to know how much my drone can "see" when I'm "spying" on them...LOL.    I show them and let them watch and as a result I alleviate a lot of the fears and misconceptions they had about drones.   
I think this article is another piece designed to be anti-drone.
